intro: Chaetanthera revoluta, commonly known as the rolling hair vetch, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive, hairy, and often twisted stems. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in racemes, and its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three oval-shaped leaflets. Chaetanthera revoluta is typically found in moist, wooded areas and is adapted to thrive in partial shade. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
